Description: Body sherd of Chian Simple Animal Style pottery chalice with part of handle zone; white slip; interior glazed (fired red in places); exterior: painted decoration consisting of lion seated to right (rump, hind legs and part of tail remaining) above two narrow dilute bands; below, group of four vertical bars; at right, double saw-edged metope pattern; below, glazed area.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Dupont and Thomas (2006, p. 79, NAU26), the geophysical characteristics of the fabric indicate that the sherd originated in Chios. The sample number is written in ink 'NAU 26' on break. Lions are usually depicted on Chalice style chalices seated facing right whilst sphinxes are seated facing left. Although Lemos does not specifically list this sherd in her fourth stage of the Group of the Simple Figures, the poor quality of the design on the exterior surface fits this grouping quite well. Figures portrayed on vases from this stage are poorly executed. Rim patterns and handle zones are disorderly. For parallels regarding the body shape and handle zone pattern, see Reading 26.2.62.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 292, no. 909, pl. 121)
Dupont & Thomas 2006 / Naukratis: Les Importations Grecques Orientales Archaïques (p. 78-79, 82-83, fig. 1) (NAU 26)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1206) (phase 2)
